Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 37373  
May 2006 
 
 
 
 
Republic of Tajikistan:  
Preparing the Dushanbe–Kyrgyz Republic Border 
Road Rehabilitation Project (Phase III) 
(Financed by the Japan Special Fund)  
 
Prepared by [Author(s)] 
[Firm] 
[Address] 
 
Prepared for  [Executing Agency] 
    [Implementing Agency] 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 20 April 2006) 
 
Currency Unit –  somoni (TJS) 
TJS1.00 =  $0.3112 
$1.00 =  TJS3.2131 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
CAREC  –  Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
ECRD  –  East Asia Department of ADB 
FMA  –  financial management assessment 
IEE  –  initial environmental examination 
km  –  kilometer 
MOT  –  Ministry of Transport 
PPTA  –  project preparatory technical assistance 
PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
RRP  –  report and recommendation of the President  
SDAP  –  social development action plan 
TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Transport and communications 
Subsector  –  Roads and highways 
Themes  –  Regional cooperation and sustainable economic growth 
Subthemes  –  Promoting  economic  efficiency  and  enabling  markets, 
and fostering physical infrastructure development  
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
Vice President  C. Lawrence Greenwood, Jr., Operations Group 2 
Director General  H. Rao, East Asia Department (EARD) 
Director  N. Rayner, Transport Division, EARD 
   
Team leader  X. Yang, Financial Specialist, EARD 
Team members  S. Ferguson, Senior Resettlement Specialist, EARD 
  R. Ishenaliev, Transport Specialist, Central and West Department 
  A. Maxwell, Environment Specialist, EARD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During the 2005 Country Programming Mission for Tajikistan, the Government confirmed 
its request for technical assistance (TA) to prepare Phase III of the Dushanbe–Kyrgyz Republic 
Border Road Rehabilitation Project (the Project).1 An Asian Development Bank (ADB) Fact-
Finding  Mission  visited  Tajikistan  in  January  2006  carried  out  an  initial  poverty  and  social 
assessment and a rapid environmental assessment, and discussed project-related issues with 
Government officials. This report is based on the agreement reached with the Government on the 
objectives, scope, costs, terms of reference, and implementation arrangements for the TA and the 
mission’s findings in the field.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Tajikistan experienced steady economic growth of more than 8% annually between 1999 
and 2004 because of the Government’s reform program and growth of the region as a whole. 
Despite rapid economic growth, Tajikistan remains the poorest of the Central Asian republics, 
with a gross domestic product per capita of about $309 in 2004.2 More than 64% of the 
population lives below national poverty line, with women and children the most affected. About 
93% of Tajikistan is mountainous. In border and mountain areas, travel is limited to only a few 
corridors and passes. Economic growth in Tajikistan depends largely on the country’s ability to 
(i) overcome the challenge of its physical location, (ii) continue to promote policy reforms that 
remove cross-border barriers to both goods and people, and (iii) establish transport links to 
larger markets. In the context of the regional cooperation, this can be achieved.  
 
3.  Promoting regional cooperation is one of the strategic themes under ADB’s long-term 
strategic  framework  (2001–2015),3 regional  cooperation  strategy,4 and  country  strategy  for 
Tajikistan (footnote 2). ADB’s partnerships with Central Asian republics focus on the Central 
Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) Program,5 which addresses one of the most 
daunting  development  challenges  of  the  region:  its  isolated  and  remote  location.  CAREC 
addresses large infrastructure needs and related policy issues affecting Afghanistan, Azerbaijan, 
Kazakhstan,  Kyrgyz  Republic,  Tajikistan,  Mongolia,  Uzbekistan,  and  the  Xinjiang  Uighur 
Autonomous Region of the People’s Republic of China (PRC). The Government of Tajikistan 
supports ADB’s regional cooperation initiative and joined the program right after it became a 
member of ADB in 1998. 
 
4.  Regional cooperation in Central Asia is still in its early stages. Intraregional traffic is 
small compared to traffic with the outside world, accounting for only 35% of imports and 11% of 
exports.6 However, economic linkages between Tajikistan and its neighbors have strengthened 
in recent years. In 2004, trade between Tajikistan and its four neighboring countries grew by 
34%  over  the  2003  figure  to  $476  million.  Despite  progress,  constraints  on  cross-border 
transport continue to hinder further expansion of trade between Tajikistan and its neighbors. 
The road sections to be rehabilitated under the Project form a bottleneck that obstructs trade 
between much of Tajikistan, Afghanistan, and adjacent countries to the south; and Osh in the 
Kyrgyz Republic (a traditional crossroads for trade), Xinjiang, and neighboring countries to the 
north. The significance of this bottleneck is evident in the PRC’s share of total trade of countries 
in the region. Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic have direct road access to the PRC that 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 31 January 2006. 
2  ADB. 2005. Country Strategy and Program Update (2006–2008): Tajikistan.  Manila. 
3  ADB. 2001. Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank (2001–2015). Manila. 
4  ADB. 2005. Central Asia Regional Cooperation Strategy and Program Update (2006–2008). Manila. 
5  http://www.adb.org/carec. 
6  ADB. 2004. Regional Cooperation Strategy and Program for CAREC Member Countries (2005–2007). Manila.

2   
does not pass through this bottleneck. The PRC’s share of total trade of these countries is 
14.2%  and  23.0%,  respectively.  However,  the  road  connecting  PRC  with  Tajikistan  and 
Afghanistan does pass through the bottleneck. PRC’s share of total trade with these countries in 
2004 was only 3% for Tajikistan and 1% for Afghanistan. In addition to the need to improve 
regional corridors, border roads are poor, border facilities inadequate, and cross-border road 
transport procedures neither friendly nor harmonized. The key to addressing these constraints is 
to phase in concrete projects that bring tangible benefits for achieving longer-term strategic 
objectives. 
 
5.  Road is the most important transport mode in Tajikistan. In 2004, roads carried 79% of 
the country’s total passenger traffic in terms of passenger-kilometer (km) and 59% of the total 
freight traffic (ton-km). Tajikistan’s economic growth has substantially increased the demand for 
transport services. Demand for road transport has outpaced that of other transport modes. 
Between 2000 and 2004, road transport demand has risen by an average of 40–50% per 
annum. The combined length of Tajikistan’s road network is about 31,800 km, consisting of 
4,800 km of national and 27,000 km of local roads. The Ministry of Transport (MOT) has 
jurisdiction over 13,800 km, including all of the national roads and 33% of the local roads 
(9,000 km). The remaining 18,000 km of local roads are mostly farm-to-farm and industrial 
access links. Most of the network was constructed before 1970 and is badly deteriorated as a 
result of civil conflict, frequent natural disasters, and inadequate maintenance. The roads were 
not built to support the large volume of heavy trucks that increasingly use them. More urgent 
than new construction is the need to upgrade existing roads to meet the demands of sustained 
economic growth and reduce poverty in the medium term.  
 
6.  One  lesson  learned  from  ADB’s  previous  projects  in  CAREC  countries  is  that 
expenditures on road maintenance should be increased. To address this, all ongoing ADB-
financed road projects in Tajikistan include loan covenants on road maintenance financing. The 
issue is also addressed through TA to ensure that the maintenance funds are used efficiently, 
including TA 4294-TAJ: Strengthening Implementation of Road Maintenance, attached to Loan 
2062-TAJ (footnote 13) which will develop a new strategy to optimize the use of funds available 
for maintenance. ADB is also providing assistance to the development of community-based 
means of maintaining rural roads, which will reduce dependency on the national budget.7 With 
the assistance of ADB-financed projects and the associated policy dialogue, the Government 
has made substantial progress in improving road maintenance, particularly financing. However, 
given the difficult mountainous terrain and size of the road network, and the continued budget 
constraints relative to demand, much more work is needed to deal with the road maintenance 
challenges.  
 
7.  The Government is implementing a poverty reduction strategy paper. Much progress has 
been made in Tajikistan toward reducing poverty—the incidence of which dropped from 83% in 
1999 to 64% in 2003—but much remains to be done. In particular, there is more scope for 
regional transport sector cooperation to improve the lives of people living in remote areas. 
Approximately 80,000 people live in the two districts, Dzhirgatal and Tajikabad, through which the 
proposed third phase project road passes. The project area was the scene of heavy fighting 
during Tajikistan’s civil war in the mid-1990s and is farther from Dushanbe and thus more remote 
than the second phase project area. The poverty incidence in the project area is likely to be 
similar to the 68% incidence for the second phase. There are many reasons for the poverty, but 
poor road access is an important one. Because of the poor transportation network between 
agriculture producers and consumer markets, transportation of goods has become very costly for 
                                                 
7  ADB. 2005. Grant Assistance to the Republic of Tajikistan for the Community-Based Rural Roads Maintenance 
Project. Manila.

3
growers.8 Before independence, the project area in the Rasht Valley produced large quantities of 
fruit and vegetables, which were exported throughout the former Soviet Union. However, fruit 
production in the project area has declined by more than half since independence.  
 
8.  Tajikistan’s road safety record in the mid-1990s was poor, with a fatality rate of 407 per 
10,000 vehicles.9 However, the situation has considerably improved since the peace agreement 
of 1997 and implementation of the Accident Prevention Plan by the Transport Safety and 
Security Unit under MOT. Although the number of vehicles has increased substantially, the 
numbers of road accidents and fatalities have remained relatively stable, lowering the fatality 
rate in 2004 to 8 per 10,000 vehicles. However, the number of accidents has increased since 
2000. There were 1,402 accidents nationwide in 2003 compared with 1,333 in 2000. The 
situation is also hampered by a lack of funds. With the present rate of growth in vehicle 
ownership in Tajikistan, the potential for more road accidents exists unless urgent action is 
taken to address this issue.  
 
9.  ADB has provided loans for improving a number of regional transport corridors10 and TA 
to prepare investment projects and undertake studies to harmonize transport regulations and 
simplify  cross-border  road  and/or  rail  transport  procedures  in  CAREC  countries.  ADB  has 
provided four loans and six TA projects totaling $74.6 million to assist the Tajikistan road 
subsector. The first project11 was completed successfully, and the second project12 will be 
completed by June 2006. The third project13 is being implemented satisfactorily, and the fourth 
one14 will be implemented shortly. All previous TA contributed to project preparations, road 
subsector policy dialogues, and reforms in Tajikistan. Lessons learned from these projects will 
be incorporated in the design of the proposed project. ADB has, since 1998, been deeply 
engaged  in  policy  dialogue  that  has  achieved  substantial  progress  in  establishing  a  legal 
framework for transport sector institutions through the passage of laws and regulations. Less 
progress has been made in commercializing transport enterprises. To address this issue, the 
Government agreed to introduce competitive bidding with private sector participation for road 
maintenance of the completed sections under the Road Rehabilitation Project (footnote 12).  
 
10.  The proposed Project will continue ADB’s improvement in the key regional corridor, 
focusing on the remaining 121 km section between Dushanbe and the Kyrgyz Republic border  
                                                 
8  According to Ministry of Agriculture, about 10 organizations provide services in cotton processing, storage, 
shipping, and sale, for which they charge up to 40% of the cotton sale price.  
9  ADB. 1995. Technical Assistance for Regional Initiatives in Road Safety Project. Manila. 
10 The regional transport corridors improved or to be improved with ADB assistance in CAREC countries include the 
Almaty–Astana road, Almaty–Bishkek road, Bishkek–Osh road, Osh–Irkeshtam road, Dushanbe–Kyrgyz Republic 
border  road,  central  north–south  road  in  Mongolia,  east–west  and  southern  highways  in  Azerbaijan,  and 
Chengeldy–Khodjadavlet railway line in Uzbekistan. 
11 ADB. 1999. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan and 
Technical Assistance Grant to the Republic of Tajikistan for the Emergency Flood Rehabilitation Project. Manila; 
and ADB. 2004. Project Completion Report with an Appended Technical Assistance Completion Report on the 
Emergency Flood Rehabilitation Project in Tajikistan. Manila.  
12 ADB. 2000. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan and 
Technical Assistance Grant to the Republic of Tajikistan for the Road Rehabilitation Project. Manila. 
13 ADB. 2003. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan and 
Technical Assistance Grant to the Republic of Tajikistan for the Dushanbe–Kyrgyz Border Road Rehabilitation 
Project (Phase I). Manila. 
14 ADB. 2005. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on the Proposed Loan and 
Asian Development Fund Grant to the Republic of Tajikistan for the Dushanbe–Kyrgyz Border Road Rehabilitation 
Project (Phase II). Manila.

4   
(Map 1).15 In addition, about 100 km of rural roads in the project area will also be rehabilitated. 
By improving key sections of the road from Dushanbe to the Tajik–Kyrgyz Republic border, the 
Project will substantially reduce this obstruction to trade and will facilitate trade and cooperation 
between countries north of the project road, including the PRC and the Kyrgyz Republic, and 
those to the south, including Tajikistan and Afghanistan. More broadly, improving the project 
road will also facilitate access to ocean ports in Pakistan to the south, and to the Russian 
Federation to the north, and lower transport costs for Central Asian republics’ exports and 
imports (Map 2). The Project also provides the only substantial link between the Rasht Valley 
and Dushanbe. Rehabilitating the project roads will improve access to Dushanbe and other 
cities in the region, which offer higher prices for agricultural products and more job opportunities 
than in the immediate project area. The Project will have significant potential for generating 
employment and income and reducing poverty in Tajikistan by fostering greater cooperation 
among neighboring countries. 
 
11.  ADB’s strategic priorities for the regional transport sector focus on (i) harmonizing and 
simplifying cross-border transport procedures and documentations among the CAREC countries 
to facilitate the movement of passengers and freight cross borders; (ii) harmonizing transport 
regulations among the CAREC countries to create a level playing field for transport operators 
and promote more efficient and better services; (iii) developing and improving regional and 
international  transport  corridors  to  link  production  centers  and  markets  within  the  CAREC 
countries, and to improve their access to neighboring regions and markets; (iv) restructuring and 
modernizing railways through private sector participation and improved corporate governance; 
and (v) improving sector funding and management to ensure that the regional transport network 
is properly developed and maintained.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Output 
 
12.  The  TA  will  help  enhance  regional  cooperation  and  sustainable  socioeconomic 
development in CAREC countries by rehabilitating the regional transport corridor in Tajikistan. The 
TA  will  (i)  help  the  Government  prepare  the  proposed  Project  suitable  for  ADB  financing, 
(ii) review and refine the project design to strengthen its features for impact on poverty reduction 
and regional cooperation, and (iii) review road subsector issues and enhance the ongoing policy 
dialogue with the Government. The output will be a project suitable for ADB financing. A design 
and monitoring framework outlining the expected impact, outcome, outputs, and activities is in 
Appendix 1.  
  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
13.  The initial poverty and social assessment and rapid environmental assessment (Appendix 
2)  carried  out  during  TA  fact-finding  concluded  that  environmental  and  social  impacts  are 
expected to be minimal, as the Project will rehabilitate the existing alignment, except for minor 
deviations due to difficult geotechnical conditions or to improve safety. Very minor resettlement 
impacts are anticipated. The initial poverty and social assessment concluded that the proposed 
Project should be classified as category B from the perspective of both involuntary resettlement 
and indigenous peoples, requiring a short resettlement plan and a social development action plan 
that  includes  specific  measures  for  ethnic  minorities.  The  rapid  environmental  assessment 
                                                 
15 The total length of Dushanbe–Kyrgyz Republic Border road is 350 km. ADB approved a loan (Phase I) of 
$15 million for improving 140 km of the first section in 2003, and a loan (Phase II) of $29.5 million for improving 
77 km of the central section and also 12 km of the road adjacent to the border in 2005. The phase I and phase II 
projects also include improvement of, respectively, 77 km and 60 km of rural roads.

5
concluded that the proposed Project should be classified as environmental category B, which 
requires an initial environmental impact examination (IEE) and a summary IEE including an 
environmental  management  plan.  The  TA  will  prepare  an  investment  project  that  will  be 
technically, economically, and financially feasible and in compliance with ADB’s policies on the 
environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples. The TA will develop a results-
based project framework including monitoring indicators for development impacts and baseline 
data. The key activities will include field surveys, document collection and review, data analysis, 
and  discussion  with  stakeholders,  including  government  officials,  project  beneficiaries,  and 
affected people.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The  total  cost  of  the  TA  is  estimated  at  $770,000  equivalent.  The  Government  has 
requested ADB to finance $650,000 equivalent (Appendix 3). The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The Government will 
finance the balance of $120,000 equivalent by providing counterpart staff, office facilities, and 
other support services. The Government has been advised that approval of the TA does not 
commit ADB to finance any ensuing project.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.   MOT will be the Executing Agency and will appoint a project coordinator from its project 
implementation unit to be responsible for day-to-day implementation of the TA and to provide 
administrative and technical support to the consultants.  
 
16.  An international consulting firm in association with domestic consultants will be selected 
and engaged by ADB, using the simplified technical proposal procedures based on the quality-
and cost-based selection method and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for selecting and 
engaging domestic consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. 
The TA will require about 13 person-months of international and 40 person-months of domestic 
consulting services, spread over 6.5 months, to carry out the study as defined in the terms of 
reference  (Appendix 4).  The international consultants  will  have had extensive experience in 
(i) transport economics including financial management, (ii) highway engineering, (iii) geotechnical 
and environmental analysis, (iv) structure and bridge engineering, (v) road maintenance and 
safety, and (vi) poverty and social analysis. The international consultants will utilize domestic 
consultants with expertise in (i) highway engineering including structural, pavement, geotechnical, 
hydraulic,  and  drainage  engineering;  (ii)  transport  economics;  (iii)  road  safety;  (iv)  road 
maintenance; (v) poverty and social analysis; (vi) environmental analysis; (vii) project costing; and 
(viii) survey engineering. The consultants will be based full-time in Dushanbe, with a field office in 
Dzhirgatal or Nimich during fieldwork. Equipment to be provided under the TA will be procured in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines. The consultants are expected to begin services 
in May 2006 and complete work by November 2006. Their final report will be made publicly 
available on ADB website upon TA completion, as required by ADB’s public communication 
policy.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $650,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Tajikistan  for  preparing  the  Dushanbe–Kyrgyz  Republic  Border  Road 
Rehabilitation Project (Phase III), and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 2 
SOCIAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENTS 
 
I.  Initial Poverty and Social Assessment 
 
  A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 
       
Is  the  sector  identified  as  a  national    Yes  Is the sector identified as a national   Yes 
priority in country poverty analysis?      priority in country poverty partnership   
      No  agreement?      No 
 
Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Tajikistan: 
The road subsector contributes to poverty reduction directly through improved access to markets and reduced 
transport costs for agricultural products, employment opportunities, and social services and, indirectly, through 
stimulating economic development. 
 
  B.  Poverty Analysis       Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
Tajikistan is the poorest of the Central Asian republics. The poverty incidence in the project area is expected to be 
higher than the national incidence, with a preliminary estimate of 64% in 2004. The project area is rural and 
mountainous, and agriculture is the primary economic activity. The project road provides the area’s only access to the 
capital and to other urban areas. By improving the project and rural roads, the Project will alleviate poverty by reducing 
the cost of road transport and improving the access of the rural poor population to market opportunities, other 
economic activities, and social services. The Project will also generate employment in construction for local residents. 
 
A detailed poverty analysis will be carried out as part of the technical assistance to identify the causes of poverty in the 
project area and demonstrate how the Project will help reduce poverty by incorporating specific measures in the 
project scope. The analysis will be based on the Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis and Handbook for 
Integrating Poverty Impact Assessment in the Economic Analysis of Projects. 
 
  C.  Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
 
Through public consultation and a detailed socioeconomic survey, stakeholder analysis will be carried out by the 
Executing Agency and the consultants during the preparation of the initial environmental examination and the social 
and poverty impact analysis. 
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
 
If required, this can be formulated during the project preparatory stage. 
 
  D.  Gender Development 
 
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
Economic opportunities for women, especially female heads of households, will be promoted during design, 
construction, and operation, including improvement of transport services. 
 
It is anticipated that women will benefit significantly from the Project in terms of improved access to health and other 
social services and faster travel times between communities. During the project preparatory technical assistance 
(PPTA), a participatory and interactive process of consultation will be carried out with female and male community 
members. Key needs and constraints identified by the communities and summarized in the social and poverty impact 
assessments will be considered in the project design. Economic opportunities for female heads of households will be 
promoted during construction. 
 
 
Has an output been prepared?      Yes     No

Appendix 3  11 
COST ESTIMATES AND FINANCING PLAN

12  Appendix 4 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTING SERVICES 
 
1.  The tasks under the technical assistance (TA) will include the following five categories. 
 
A.  Regional Cooperation and Transport Sector Review 
 
2.  Assess the regional benefit of Phase III of the Dushanbe–Kyrgyz Republic Border Road 
Rehabilitation Project (the Project) and its role in the regional transport network, identify major 
constraints, and recommend how to integrate the project corridor to strengthen economic linkages 
between Tajikistan and other Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) countries. 
 
3.  Review the current status of trade between Tajikistan and other CAREC countries. Evaluate 
the  potential  for  trade development  between  Tajikistan  and  other  CAREC  countries  after  the 
completion of the proposed Dushanbe–Kyrgyz Republic border roads network. Assess the impact 
of the Project on trade in the short and long term. Review customs procedures and requirements, 
based on work done under the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Loan 2114-TAJ.16 Assess the 
border crossing in terms of (i) frequency and number of freight and public transport services, 
(ii) freight and passenger volumes, (iii) access distance into neighboring countries, (iv) time spent 
on  border  crossing,  and  (v)  potential  increase  in  trade  volume  via  the  border  crossing.  In 
consultation with Tajikistan customs, design a suitable component to facilitate regional traffic and 
economic cooperation focusing on (i) physical infrastructure and associated services needed to 
improve cross-border facility and operations, (ii) conducting a preliminary design of the cross-
border  facility,  (iii)  capacity  building,  and  (iv)  measures  to  be  included  in  the  bilateral  and 
multilateral border-crossing agreements to maximize regional traffic movements.  
 
4.  Review ongoing initiatives for harmonizing cross-border transport procedures and tariffs 
under ADB’s CAREC and similar initiatives by others. Conduct a specific study of instituting cross-
border transport tariffs and recommend regulations to be amended and new regulations to be 
adopted based on the findings. 
 
5.  Review road revenue and expenditure in Tajikistan for 2000–2005 and make a projection 
for 2006–2010. Analyze the expenses for maintenance of main roads and local roads under 
Ministry  of  Transport  (MOT)  jurisdiction  and  financing  plans  for  future  maintenance.  Identify 
constraints and recommend action plans for improvement. Examine the role of the road subsector 
in Tajikistan and analyze how improved roads contribute to poverty reduction. 
 
6.  Conduct a financial management assessment (FMA) of MOT, including the completion of 
ADB’s FMA questionnaire. The FMA will include a review of MOT’s systems for financial and 
management accounting, reporting, auditing and internal controls, and disbursement and cash flow 
management. Identify issues or risks associated with the financial management systems and 
determine the most appropriate risk-mitigation measures to be adopted as part of project design 
and  implementation  arrangements.  Identify  issues  or  risks  associated  with  the  financial 
management systems and determine the most appropriate risk mitigation measures to be adopted 
as part of project design and implementation arrangements. 
 
7.  Review highway design and construction standards currently in use in Tajikistan, study the 
relevant project experiences, and suggest whether the standards prepared under the previous 
ADB TA 5733-REG17 are acceptable and applicable. Identify excessive road design standards 
which were not based on sound economic rationale. Recommend and adopt appropriate standards 
that will make use of local standards and comply with good international practices. 
 
                                                 
16  ADB. 2004. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on Proposed Loans and Technical 
Assistance Grants to the Republic of Tajikistan and Kyrgyz Republic for the Regional Customs Modernization and 
Infrastructure Development Project. Manila. 
17 ADB. 1997. Regional Technical Assistance for a Review of Road Design and Construction Standards. Manila.

Appendix 4  13 
8.  Review current design methodology in relation to road safety. Assess road traffic accident 
statistics nationally and in the project corridor. In consultation with MOT and the Ministry of Internal 
Affairs, recommend a suitable road safety component for inclusion in the Project and prepare the 
terms of reference for further studies. Conduct technical training for relevant Government officers in 
compiling and analyzing a traffic accident statistical database. 
 
9.  Review the implementation of ADB-financed road projects and TA in Tajikistan to extract the 
lessons learned from earlier interventions and to incorporate these into the project design. Review 
and update the transport sector profile, including Institutional and Policy Support to the Road Sector 
(TA 3602), attached to Loan 181918 and identify areas requiring advisory TA or detailed follow-up 
studies. Prepare the rationale and terms of references for possible advisory TA for strengthening 
MOT and its governance.  
 
B.  Feasibility Study and Preliminary Design  
 
10.  Conduct traffic surveys at appropriate locations including classified traffic counts and origin-
destination and axle-load surveys to establish the pattern and volume of vehicle, passenger, and 
cargo movements. Include details on passenger characteristics and type of freight being shipped. 
Assess the possibility of passenger and freight traffic generated by the Project or diverted from 
other routes. Prepare traffic forecasts by representative vehicle type, taking into account population 
growth, production increase, economic activity, and income in the hinterland of the project road. 
Quantify the volume and describe the composition of international traffic and transnational transit 
traffic.  
 
11.  Assess the right-of-way requirements for the project roads and establish project boundaries. 
Carry out detailed topographic surveys in a manner to achieve reliable cost estimates. Investigate 
the structural strength of the existing pavement and its ability to sustain the forecast traffic by visual 
inspections,  deflection  measurements,  and  laboratory  tests  on  samples  taken  from  test  pits. 
Assess the functional or riding quality of the pavement by conducting roughness measurements. 
Identify sources of the local construction materials and investigate their suitability and properties by 
sampling  and  testing  them.  Assess  the  need  for  imported  construction  materials,  particularly 
bitumen and steel, and identify possible sources. Based on the results of topographic surveys and 
investigations, and taking into account of the extreme weather and terrain conditions, determine 
the most cost-effective way of improving the road alignment (including re-alignment options to 
bypass  problem  sections)  and  pavement  to  accommodate  the  forecast  traffic.  Prepare  a 
preliminary design including alignment plans, longitudinal sections, and typical embankment and 
pavement cross-sections. Include in the preliminary design necessary ancillary works and road 
safety features such as traffic barriers, signal posts, pedestrian crossings, and street lights in 
villages and other population centers. If warranted by the social survey, include possible locations 
for roadside stations to provide such services as the sale of fuel and local goods. Prepare an 
itemized bill of quantities for all road works. 
 
12.  Examine rockfall and landslide hazards, study the properties of rocks and soils on mountain 
slopes and the stability of embankment and cutting slopes, and propose cost-effective methods for 
remedial action. Study the geology, soil and rock properties, and hydrology of the problem areas. 
Prepare a preliminary design for the chosen remedial structures. Study the feasibility of retaining 
walls, galleries, and tunnels to address difficult topographical and geological road conditions, if 
applicable.  Examine  existing  bridges,  culverts  and  other  drainage  structures,  and  retaining 
structures on the project roads to determine their condition, adequacy, load-bearing capacity, 
anticipated  future  serviceability,  and  the  general  extent  of  repairs  and  strengthening  needed. 
Suggest new drainage structures where warranted by the hydrological survey results. Prepare 
preliminary designs for improvement and newly proposed drainage structures and produce typical 
drawings, including plan location, typical longitudinal and cross sections, and details of major 
elements. Prepare an itemized bill of quantities for all structures. 
                                                 
18  ADB. 2000. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan and 
Technical Assistance Grant to the Republic of Tajikistan for the Road Rehabilitation Project. Manila.

14  Appendix 4 
 
13.  Prepare a bill of quantities for the general items, such as insurance, project site, engineer’s 
facilities, etc. All preliminary design work, including typical drawings and bills of quantities, need to 
be prepared in a manner suitable and sufficient for the contractor to (i) prepare the final design 
based on the preliminary design and (ii) be able to price each work item. Prepare cost estimates 
for the road sections, indicating a breakdown of foreign and local costs and of tax and duty 
components. Suggest contract packages and a project implementation schedule. Prepare cost 
estimates for maintenance of the project road following project completion based on country- and 
site-specific factors. Prepare a road maintenance program for the project road, including a plan for 
monitoring and addressing the impact of natural events such as landslides and floods on the 
project road.  
 
14.  Review the secondary and tertiary road network in the project area in consultation with 
MOT and local communities; develop rural roads screening and prioritization criteria, taking into 
consideration poverty-reduction and other economic and social factors; and identify priority local 
roads for inclusion in the Project. Conduct field surveys and undertake detailed engineering for the 
local  roads.  Prepare  contractor  prequalification  and  bidding  documents  for  local  roads  in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2006).  
 
15.  Undertake an economic evaluation of all project components in accordance with the ADB’s 
Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects (2007) by comparing the with- and without-project 
cases. Calculate the economic internal rate of return and net present value for the individual 
project components and the overall project. A standard conversion factor or a shadow exchange 
rate  factor  will  be  used.  The  analysis  should  take  into  account  construction,  operation,  and 
maintenance costs; vehicle operating costs; passenger and freight time savings; producer surplus; 
accident savings; and any other quantifiable benefits attributable to the Project. Assess the extent of 
benefits arising from reduced vehicle-operating costs that will be passed on to transport users 
through  lowered  passenger  fares  and  freight  charges.  Undertake  sensitivity  analysis  by 
appropriately varying benefits, costs, implementation period, traffic diversion, generated traffic, and a 
combination of these factors. Benefits from increased agricultural and other production, including 
those  due  to  the  improved  rural  roads,  and  increased  trade  should  also  be  examined  and 
quantified, if relevant. Estimate separately the benefits arising from international traffic as the 
overall corridor is rehabilitated. Examine impacts such as regional/national economic development, 
improved road safety, etc. Taking into consideration the economic evaluation, least cost analysis, 
social benefits, and environmental impact, recommend the most suitable kind of road rehabilitation 
and/or  improvement  options  and  rank  the  recommended  improvements  by  priority.  Economic 
analysis  should  bring  in  findings  from  reports  on  regional  cooperation  and  consider  regional 
cooperation benefits that can be measured directly under the Project. Carry out risk analysis and 
recommend ways in which project risks can be reduced.  
 
16.  Carry out distribution analysis of project benefits among countries in the region and, to 
examine the Project’s impact on beneficiaries in Tajikistan, calculate the poverty impact ratio and 
undertake a cause-and-effect analysis, following the methodology set forth in Appendixes 25 and 
26 of ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects (1997).  
 
17.  Formulate, in a participatory manner, a results-based project performance management 
system,19 using  the  design  and  monitoring  framework  in  an  ADB  format,  including  monitoring 
indicators that will be used to assess project performance, as well as baseline and target values for 
the selected indicators. Develop a detailed monitoring framework for selected villages in the project 
area and a control area and collect baseline data and target values for key indicators. 
 
18.  Review the budget position of the borrower and MOT to determine the potential impact of 
recurring costs on the overall financial position. Assess the financial sustainability of the Project, 
including  (i)  projecting  the  forward  incremental  recurrent  costs  associated  with  the  Project, 
                                                 
19  ADB. 2005. Project Performance Management System: Guidelines for Preparing a Design and Monitoring Framework. 
Manila.

Appendix 4  15 
(ii) assessing forward debt-service obligation, (iii) comparing total forward cash outlay requirements 
against the current MOT budget, and (iv) presenting a conclusion with respect to the sustainability 
of the Project. Suggest appropriate financial covenants to monitor the financial conditions of the 
Project. 
 
C.  Social and Poverty Analysis and Social Development Action Plan 
 
19.  Prepare socioeconomic and poverty profiles for the project area. The information should 
include population, income, occupations, unemployment, education, health, transport expenditures, 
and other relevant socioeconomic data, disaggregated by gender and ethnicity. Poverty incidence 
will be assessed based on Government poverty lines and $2.15 per day (in purchasing power 
parity  terms  as  defined  by  the  World  Bank).  Review  the  Government’s  policy,  strategy,  and 
programs for poverty reduction and regional economic development. Pay particular attention to 
policies and programs that target vulnerable people in the project area, including ethnic minorities. 
Analyze  how  the  proposed  Project  will  complement  the  Government’s  ongoing  and  future 
development programs. Consult with the Government to identify development initiatives that could 
complement the Project, particularly those targeting the poor, women, and ethnic minorities, and 
identify possible sources of funding for these initiatives. Prepare a summary poverty reduction and 
social assessment. 
 
20.  Prepare a poverty and social analysis in accordance with ADB’s Handbook on Poverty and 
Social Analysis (2001), Handbook for Integrating Poverty Impact Assessment in the Economic 
Analysis of Projects (2001), and Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998). Assess how the Project will 
improve  people’s  income  and  livelihoods.  Assess  the  risks  of  HIV/AIDS,  sexually  transmitted 
infections, and human and drug trafficking due to the Project and propose mitigation measures for 
any  high-risk  groups.  Recommend  measures  and  actions  to  enhance  benefits  and  minimize 
adverse impacts, particularly for the poor, women, ethnic minorities, and other vulnerable groups. 
The proposed actions should be formulated into a social development action plan (SDAP). Special 
measures  for  ethnic  minorities  must  be included  in  the SDAP  in  order  to  (i)  safeguard  their 
livelihoods and customs and (ii) enhance project benefits in a culturally appropriate manner. The 
cost of such measures and means for implementation must be clearly proposed in the SDAP.  
 
21.  Establish  consultation  and  participatory  processes  during  project  preparation  that  will 
continue throughout project design, construction, and operation. Stakeholders should be identified 
and representatives consulted so their needs and demands can be considered for incorporation 
into the Project or as parallel initiatives. Prepare a public participation and consultation report, 
providing  details  of  consultation  meetings  during  project  preparation,  including  responsible 
agencies, the date, the number and occupations of participants, and their responses. Prepare a 
public participation and consultation plan and monitoring format for project implementation. This 
consultation  plan  can  combine  environmental,  social,  and  resettlement  aspects.  Help  MOT 
disclose the SDAP to local people. Provide training to MOT staff in social assessment, participatory 
community appraisal, consultation, and participatory monitoring techniques. 
 
D.  Resettlement Planning  
 
22.  Help MOT prepare a resettlement plan covering the main road, local road upgrading, and 
any  associated  facilities  to  comply  with  ADB’s  Involuntary  Resettlement  (1995).  Conduct 
resettlement household surveys20 and surveys of seriously affected households to ensure adequate 
understanding of social impacts. Quantify the types and degree of impacts on affected people, 
including  income  levels  and  sources,  housing  conditions,  occupations,  expenditure  patterns, 
landholdings, skills bases, and assets. Determine and document in the resettlement plan the extent 
to which the project design and alignment has avoided or minimized land acquisition and the 
displacement of people and businesses. Assess the impacts on the poor, ethnic groups, women, 
                                                 
20 For household surveys, ADB requires at least 10% of affected people and enterprises and 20% of seriously affected 
people to be surveyed. Note that the design institute may commence some surveys prior to TA commencement. The 
number of surveys can be finalized during the inception phase.

16  Appendix 4 
and  other  vulnerable  groups.  Identify  potential  impoverishment  risks  and  vulnerable  groups, 
including those severely affected through loss of land and those with low income, and develop 
special mitigation measures as required. The assessment of resettlement impacts should cover all 
components  under  the  scope  of  the  Project,  including  temporary  impacts  caused  during 
construction. 
  
23.  Define categories for impact and the eligibility of affected people for compensation, and 
prepare an entitlements matrix covering compensation and other assistance for all types of impacts 
to achieve full replacement for lost assets, income, and livelihoods. For affected households, 
assess  the  risks  from  land  acquisition  and  related  project  impacts  and  prepare  appropriate 
rehabilitation measures to ensure they are not worse off as a result of the Project. Special attention 
should be paid to vulnerable households and measures to help them improve their standard of 
living. Help MOT finalize, disclose, and get Government endorsement of the resettlement plan 
based on preliminary design data. Include a 3–5 page executive summary in the resettlement plan. 
 
E.  Initial Environmental Examination 
 
24.  The consultant shall prepare an initial environmental examination (IEE) and a summary IEE 
for  the  Project  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Environment  Policy  (2002),  and  Environmental 
Assessment Guidelines (2003). If the IEE indicates that significant environmental impacts are likely, 
the consultant shall prepare a detailed environmental impact assessment report. The consultant 
shall  ensure  that  the  IEE  includes  (i)  a  description  of  the  Project;  (ii)  a  description  of  the 
environment,  including  physical  resources,  ecological  resources,  economic  development,  and 
social  and  cultural  resources;  (iii)  anticipated  environmental  impacts  (direct,  indirect,  and 
cumulative)  and  mitigation  measures;  (iv)  institutional  requirements  and  an  environmental 
monitoring plan; and (v) public consultation and information disclosure.  
 
25.  The  consultant’s  specific  activities  shall  include,  but  not  be  limited  to,  the  following: 
(i) estimate  the  costs  of  implementing  the  proposed  environmental  mitigation  measures  and 
environmental  monitoring  plans,  (ii)  help  the  design  engineers  incorporate  appropriate 
environmental  mitigation  measures  into  the  project  design,  (iii)  provide  recommendations  on 
environmental training requirements, (iv) prepare terms of reference and a budget for independent 
environment monitoring and evaluation, and (v) help MOT conduct appropriate environmental 
public consultations in accordance with ADB’s Environmental Assessment Guidelines (2003).
